comments.commentBody: So, let's see,  a tax credit of $4000,  that is just about the cost of three months of my premium, paid by my employer,  for a plan that still requires up to $3500 out-of-pocket costs in deductibles and co-pays.  How is that supposed to work?

"And California-based Apple pockets most of the profit from those sales."

But it does not pocket that inside the US. It pays no taxes on it, (0.005% per reports) by keeping the money out of the country.

To call that American profits, California-based, ignores truth.
The company maintains about 80,000 employees in America. You are ignoring truth too.
Good to hear that GW Bush's decisive actions are still keeping us safe.  Hopefully our new President will soon move to fill the vacuum left by Obama.
Wishful thinking.

Clearly, Donald's most urgent problem is ratings. That seems to be as deep as he goes.

The FBI must tell the country what they know about Donald and his team. We need a government in place that we can trust is working for the country and not some more parochial interest.

The fear for those of us outside America, watching this extraordinary situation where a US President appears to be against his own Intelligence and Security Services, not to mention the media, and who shoots from the hip, is that he will lash out at another country in order to deflect attention.
After decades of opposing tyrants and despots, and having a strong defence and technological superiority over the world, America appears paralysed, confused and vulnerable, all because of a home grown 'cowboy'.

The very thought of a homicidal paranoid possessing nuclear weapons able to target all of the US is horrifying. My first reaction is 'how fast can we launch a preemptive attack and utterly destroy North Korea.?' Then I recall the studies on nuclear winter and how hundreds of millions of people (besides millions of North Koreans) would be killed by the global side effects of dropping the requisite number of warheads there.

I bet the Chinese are pretty uncomfortable with this viper they have clutched to their breast that keeps getting bigger and more poisonous. Their caution is instructive.
Yeah, well Obama probably saved your "effin" IRA from extinction, but hey, think what you want, it's a free country, for the time being.

Um....do you not see this as a problem?   We know it means "nothing" but it's supposed to mean something, and maybe once in a while it does mean something.  He's POTUS, for heaven's sake.  We can't ignore him, much as we'd like to.

Trump trumpets his deal-making skills.  But there is little evidence that these are suited to international diplomacy or any other kind of transactions between sovereign powers.  In fact Trumps range of operative skills appear limited.  His knowledge base (and inclination to master the details of a given situation) even more so

If history has any lessons to present to the future it's that in the case of North Korea, Iran and others like them each day spent kicking the can down the road will unveil a worse day tomorrow. There are no perfect or even palatable solutions to some problems, and each day spent looking for one sometimes makes the overall situation far worse. Some cancers need to be operated at the first sign of disease, and timidity and hesitation offer no shelter against them.

I remember Trump saying Obama told him what the biggest threat to US was and he said he would tell on Tuesday? but didn't. This was after their meeting together.

I predicted it was N. Korea because of Trump's sudden pivot on Taiwan, Pakistan, and very friendly engagement with Japan. With Mattis visiting, Abe's visit to the US. Of all the foreign leaders, Japan definitely got the most attention. All of this shows Trump is taking N. Korea very seriously and leveraging what he can to stop the threat or put pressure and get a better negotiating position.

I think he's doing an okay job. Certainly changing tone from the ineffective approaches of all previous administrations and Sec of State like Obama, Hillary, Bush, Clinton, etc. haven't helped. A new approach may be needed. Trump might not be so bad in quite a few cases.
Well, Obama didn't fail me.  He kept us out of war as much as he could.  He tried to disable North Korea.  What would you have had him do, drop a nuke on them?
One thing all these comments have in common is thinking there's a functioning US State Department. There currently is no such thing.
Too busy focusing on climate change, which former Secretary of State Kerry said was as big a threat as Islamic terrorism.

@AACNY
If you were actually keeping up, you'd know that the State Department is essentialy being phased out of existence, since Donald Trump has no concept of what diplomacy is.

By using non-existant nuclear weapons as the pretext to invade Iraq, Bush II pushed N. Korea and Iran into arming themselves with nuclear weapons.

Horses out, barn door shut way too late.

If our interception success rate is 56%, shouldn't that multiply by using a bunch of instances of the same systems against a given target? I guess that sounds expensive, in theory. But I'm just thinking, 56%, if you fire it a few times, from several different points along the target's route, maybe that shouldn't be too bad. You know, it's like in a field sport with goals, one defender may not stop a talented athlete, but if you give a few of them the job, maybe the second or third is able to do it.

Maybe that would compensate for failures due to poor conditions. One interceptor flies with different local conditions than another that's attacking at not the same time and place. Maybe that's not really too much for us to do.

Beyond that, though, I'm thinking that if North Korea can do as much as they do now, then maybe we should consider it just a matter of time before they can create a missile that likely enough can reach us and can evade our defenses. If not now, then decades in the future.

If nukes make the world a more dangerous place, why start by disarming the nations that are least likely to use them wrongly? If we fight climate change partly because of the threat it poses decades from now, why isn't fighting nukes for the same reason also just as important?

I'm wondering whether the solution to this really could be just to more or less destroy North Korea, the sooner the better. Why let them hold a gun to our heads? Is "left of launch" just a gimmick?
Easy to point the finger, isn't it? -- But what do base this opinion on, the fact that we're not rattling our sabers, or embroiled in some deadly war???....And are YOU willing to go?

Richard, exactly what might the threat to China be? Kim Jong-un becomes suicidal and decides to have his country destroyed?
Just more American propaganda to keep the populace frightened and distracted while TRUMP et al. fill their coffers.

Next week the story will be about the other great "threat" Iran. A country whose international dalliances pale when compared to the USA's, which occur on every continent. Look within. The picture isn't pretty, but we need to put our own house in order.

A recent Science article stated that a solar sunspot emission flareup similar to one in the 1800's could wipe out electricity on the Northeast coast for a year. It claimed it is long overdue. Therein lies the secret to the perfect defensive weapon if it could be harnessed by our scientists.
Trump 's most urgent problem is his complete alienation from the truth: his inability to speak or recognize it. Every other problem, however urgent, is subsumed to this  reality.

Your friend should have read the Constitution and the founders letters during her Ivy League education.

A Christian is a follower of Christ. Christ said nothing about abortion, ever. Period.

The GOP can't even protect the born.

Iver: That North Korea is a desperate, rogue nation with a madman at the helm and thousands of pieces of artillery aimed at Seoul, plus nuclear and long-range missile capability, is not a myth or conspiracy theory. This is real.
Gert - China is South Koreas largest trading partner.  25% of their exports go to China.  China is also one of the most popular places for South Korean pop music.  The world is a different place.
Ah but didn't we try that when Japanese ambassadors visited here pre Pearl Harbor unaware that even as they were returning home the planes were in the air?

Short of pre-emptively nuking them back into the stone age, the only solution is a three-way pact between the USA, China and South Korea, with a guarantee that if the North collapses and Korea unites, it will become neutral and de-militarised, or at least there will be no US troops anywhere in Korea.
That's the answer. We have to leave the area.

This article suggests that the targets are american cities, which would require a great number of missiles, perhaps beyond the scope of what N. Korea can attain. If however they can launch 2-3 missiles and detonate them at high altitude (1-200 miles) above the US, the EMP would destroy much of our infrastructure. That includes the power grid, autos, trucks, trains, jets, and computer devices. That's pretty much our modern civilization!
The immediate food, water, and medicine shortages would cause huge loss of life. Recovery could take months to years.
What is our governments response to this?

Bill, Most people have normalcy bias, underestimating the possibility or the potential impact of an EMP strike on the grid. Such an event would instantly transport us back into the 19th Century with most struggling to obtain even the most basic necessities such as water, food, medicine and warmth.
